etymologies: early 17th century: from late Latin syncopat- ‘affected with syncope’, from the verb syncopare ‘to swoon’ (see syncope)

definitions: displace the beats or accents in (music or a rhythm) so that strong beats become weak and vice versa

examples.text: soloists maintain the absolute freedom to syncopate the rhythm or break free from the beat entirely

shortDefinitions: displace beats or accents in music so that strong beats become weak and vice versa

definitions: shorten (a word) by dropping sounds or letters in the middle, as in symbology for symbolology, or Gloster for Gloucester.
shortDefinitions: shorten word by dropping sounds or letters in middle
